content.description:
The huge wall is climbed straight up the center pretty much. It's a little less steep than most stuff at Deadman's, so thankfully you can take your time on it without the pump setting in. The hardest moves are in the upper section, make sure you can downclimb incase they're not to your liking.

The hand crack in the corner to the left is also an excellent VB.
content.location: About 40 feet right of the Undercling Problem is a large wall facing Southwest.

content.description: One of the best problems at Deadman's. Start at the juggy sidepull, reach into the undercling, stand up and grab a cool little sidepull "ear", and then get some big jugs. Continue up and left to a big hueco and finish straight up on good holds. The crux is down low but tall to finish, and vertical the whole way.
content.location: Out the center of the alcove.

content.description:
This is the "Unnamed V4" immediately right of the Undercling Problem. It's not quite as classic as that problem, but still fun and worth getting on.

Sit start at a low big jug. Reach up left hand to a good two or three finger pocket (the belly button) and then make a big move with the right to a jug sidepull about 8 inches from the crack. Then move up and left through the buldge on good holds that might be difficult to identify. It's easy for the grade if you use all the correct holds. Finish the same as the Undercling Problem.

The crack and wall to the right is all "off". Doesn't feel contrived at all though, the moves flow naturally.
content.location: Right of the Undercling Problem. Climbs out the right side of the steep gray "belly" from a sit start.
